titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Morning visit from General Watzdorf the new Saxon Minister— He had his audiences of the Emperor and Empress yesterday— At 6 this Evening I attended the Lecture of Mr: Boucher, who has recommenced his course— But having changed his residence, which is now distant from my own house, and his present apartment being too small to admit many hearers, I shall perhaps not be very assiduous in my future attendance— I read a couple of chapters in Mallet’s Hanseatic league, but was too heavy and drowsy to read with much effect— Mrs: Adams and Catherine, both unwell— Catherine confined to her chamber— I had a fire this day made in my chamber, for the first time; but I have suffered for the want of it several days. We have indeed had fires these ten days, in two of our chambers. Finished my letter for the Secretary of State.

2. I wrote to Mr: Pinkney, and made up two packets enclosed to him with despatches for the United States— Delivered them to Mr: Navarro, who promised to send them in a small trunk, which he forwards to the Portugueze Ambassador at London. His Courier goes to-morrow afternoon. I then visited General Watzdorf, who lodges in our old apartments at the Ville de Bordeaux— Count Bussche was going in just before me— Their Conversation was on the expence of living, housekeeping and so forth, here at St: Petersburg— Bussche said he had a very small salary; and was determined to spend none of his own fortune in this detestable Country; to which if he had known what it was before he came, horses should not have dragg’d him— He chose therefore to live very economically— He had a small, but very pretty house in the City, for which he paid upwards of eight thousand Roubles a year for Rent, and which he partly furnished— His Country Seat cost him two thousand five hundred Roubles for the Summer months— And he was obliged to keep three Valets de Chambre, three footmen, a Chasseur, a Swiss, and Moozhiks he knew not how many— A Droshka, and eleven horses; each of which cost twenty-eight roubles a month to feed— General Watzdorf told us that he was 51. years old had been twice married—had two children by his first wife, one of which was a daughter, already married— That he married six years ago his present wife, and by her has three infant children from whom he found it very hard to separate himself— That he had always been in the military career untill now, and felt himself altogether a novice in diplomacy— I afterwards returned Mr: Rosenzweig’s visit; but he was not at home— Called at Mr: Donovan’s lodgings and found he had left the City— Went to see Mr: Plummer and Mr: Andrews at Rea’s, and left cards for them— Then walked untill the hour of dinner— Mr: Plummer and Mr: Navarro occupied the leisure of the Evening. Mrs: A. went to the play.— Mr: J. S. Smith called this morning, with Mr: Hollins, a Gentleman from Baltimore; kinsman to Mr: Smith.

3. Visit this morning from Mr: Fisher, with Mr: William Adgate— This Gentleman with Mr: Hollins both came from Riga, on account of a charge of sur charge of six thousand Rubles, each, against the vessels in which they came, made by the merchants to whom they had applied, to get their papers, from the Commission for neutral Navigation— On the pretence that it was for getting them admitted, although they had no certificates from the Russian Consuls— I had written & spoken, both to Baron Campenhausen and to Count Romanzoff on this subject, who had assured me that it should occasion no difficulty; and I had informed Mr: Hollins & Mr: Adgate of Baron Campenhausen’s Answer to my note respecting their vessels.— On receiving from their merchants at Riga, Klepper, Luplau & Co: notice that this demand was made by their Correspondents at St: Petersburg— Klepper— Lup Kaul and Launitz, Mr: Hollins refused to pay it, and immediately came to St: Petersburg to contest it— Adgate did the same— On their arrival here, and demanding an explanation of Messrs: Kaul and Launitz, they disclaimed having any such demand to make— Mr: Andrews, Mr: Hollins, Mr: Fisher, Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Jones, dined with us— Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray, dined at Mr: Raimbert’s— They were here in the Evening. General Watzdorf also, the Saxon Minister paid a visit this Evening to the Ladies.— I received a note from Mr: Harris, enclosing a letter to him from Mr: Gourieff, concerning the sugars—and containing an apology from Mr: Harris for not dining with us— He is confined with a cold.

4. Morning visits from Mr: Harris and Mr: Montréal—the latter of these Gentlemen mentioned to me some reports which had been circulated by the Glukoff’s, to the disadvantage of the House of Messrs: Raimbert, in regard to the business, done by them for Mr: Gray— In consequence of which Mr: Consolat was obliged to go to Cronstadt to ask an explanation of Captain Groves.— I pass’d the day and Evening at home, excepting a walk before dinner— Began this Evening to read L’Evesque’s history of Russia.

5. Captain Leach, and Captain Adams, a brother of Miss Hannah Adams called upon me this morning— And also Mr: Nankarow, Super Cargo of the schooner Bona, belonging to Baltimore, and which has just arrived at Cronstadt— Although I pass’d the morning in preparation to write, I wrote nothing— I merely read the Preface to the Art de la Corderie— By Du Hamel du Monceau—a Work which I borrowed of Mr: Raimbert to collect from it information respecting the cultivation of Hemp— I dined at Count Romanzoff, with a Company of about thirty persons— A diplomatic dinner to the new Saxon Minister General Watzdorff— I enquired of Count Romanzoff when I could have an interview with him, and he appointed me next Sunday at 12. O’Clock— The foreign Ministers were all at this dinner, and among them General Pardo, who arrived yesterday, on his return from Moscow and Makarieff— I sat between Count Lüxbourg and the Chevalier Brancia at dinner; and our conversation was of literature & politics; but not very interesting— Mr: J. S. Smith & Mr: Gray dined with the family— We had evening visits, first from Mr: Tilden & Mr: Jones, and afterwards from Mr: Fisher & Mr: Everett.

6. There was a review of troops this morning without the City, near the Convent of St: Alexander Newsky— The ladies went to see it. Mr: Stieglitz called upon me with a request for a duplicate Passport for Captain Seaman to whom I furnished one sometime since, which the Police of the City have, and which he cannot get returned to him— I told Mr: Stieglitz that Mr: Seaman must be here for the description of the person and the signature; if I gave him a second Passport.— I had visits from Mr: Raimbert, Mr: Navarro, and Count Luxbourg who engaged so completely the whole forenoon that although I rose soon after six this morning I could write only part of a private letter in the course of the day— These visits take up so much of my time that I sometimes think of taking resolutions not to receive them; but on the other hand, so much information, important to be possessed, and particularly relative to the current political events is to be collected from them that they are rather to be encouraged than discountenanced— I therefore do encourage them, and shall do so still more. Count Lüxbourg brought me Masson’s secret Memoirs of the Court of Russia, which I have long wished to see, but never before could procure— Mr: Navarro promised to lend me a copy of the Treaty of Bartenstein— The Ladies went this Evening to the play— I received notice of a Te Deum at the Palace to-morrow, for the surrender of Roustchouk & Giurgia. Mr: J. S. Smith pass’d an hour here, after the play.

7. A Mrs: Kelly came to me this morning to solicit Charity, and assistance— Her husband she says, is a native of Annapolis and served in the American Navy during the whole of our revolutionary War— In 1788. being at Copenhagen he was persuaded by Baron Krudener to come and enter the Russian Service. He had for some years the command of an armed vessel; but was dismiss’d from the service by Admiral Tchitchagoff, when he was Minister of the Marine— He has since obtained a pension of one hundred rubles a year; upon which they cannot live; and he is a cripple at Cronstadt— She wished me to make an application in his behalf to the Emperor, but that I have no right to do— I gave her some pecuniary relief— Mr: Harris to whom she has made applications before says that her husband was dismissed from the Imperial service for embezzlement of public property; and that after having served during part of the American War in our Navy, he changed sides, and finished the War on the side of the British— At Noon I attended at the Palace, for the Te Deum; both the Mr: Smiths and Mr: Gray went with me— Mr: Everett was gone to the hunt.— We were introduced to the chapel just at the close of the Mass— The Ceremony was the same as usual— It was over about two O’Clock, and I had then only time for my walk— Mr: Harris came and dined with us—and Mr: Gray— Mr: Harris also pass’d part of the Evening with us— Such was the employment of this day’s time— I read only Massillon’s Panegyric of St: Benedict; one of his most indifferent performances.— It barely alludes in general terms to the Story of this Saint, who lived in the fourth and fifth centuries, and was the founder of one of the most celebrated monastic orders of the Romish Church— They are those known in England before the Reformation by the name of Black-friyars. They were among the most highly famed for the severity of their rule of discipline; their wealth and their learning.— There is a life of this Saint written by Saint Gregory.

8. On rising this morning I found the ground and the roofs of the houses covered with snow, which had fallen in the course of the night. This may be considered as the signal for the approach of Winter— We have had since the first of this month, our double windows put in— The external windows, consist of two parts— There are six panes to each window—the panes are 25 inches long and 19 inches wide. The two uppermost are in a sash and fastened to the Walls of the house— The other four are in two corresponding door sashes suspended on both sides of the wall, and closing together with bolts upwards & downwards. The double windows are of six panes in one sash—of corresponding size with the external windows— In most of the chambers one of the windows, have one of the lower panes in the form of a door corresponding in the external and internal window, and which serves as a ventilator when occasion requires— Between the two windows a trough about an inch deep of sand closes the crack at the bottom of the external window. The cracks all round the internal window, between it and the wall, are stuff’d with oakum and a paper border is pasted over it— Thus the windows are hermetically sealed; and this is the occasion of the equable warmth which they so commonly have in this Country— Mr: Jones called upon me this forenoon, and requested me to present him at Court. I told him I would make enquiries of Count Romanzoff to ascertain whether it could be done consistently with the usages— I wrote this morning a Note to the Count, requesting him to appoint a time when he would see me, instead of the appointment which was disconcerted yesterday by the Te Deum— After calling at the house where I had seen Mr: Hynam, and finding that he had changed his lodgings, I went to the Book-shop where I have made a number of purchases, and took a few books— I Dined at Mr: Raimbert’s— The gentlemen of the legation except Mr: J. S. Smith—Mr: Harris—Mr: Plummer and Mr: Morse were there— In the Evening I read Levesque— The Ladies attended the Play.

9. I was occupied this morning in translating an imperial Manifesto concerning the organization of the Ministries; from the German; when just at ten O’Clock I received a note from Count Romanzoff requesting me to call upon him at 11. I had not time to order breakfast immediately to be prepared, before Mr: Harris came in, with Captain Bainbridge, Mr: Lynch, and Mr: Lewis— Captain Bainbridge has just arrived from America, after a detention of six weeks at Copenhagen. He brought me a packet of Letters from America— They were from my mother and brother, dated in May; two months earlier than those we have received from our friends, by Mr: Jones— I had not time to read them before I was obliged to call according to the appointment upon Count Romanzoff— I told him that I had now received the despatches from my Government, respecting the Proposition which had been made by Mr: Daschkoff, in relation to the trade, with the Indians on the North-west Coast of America— That I was directed in the first instance to declare the sincere and earnest desire of the President of the United States, to concur in any measure, which might be useful to the Russian dominions, and agreeable to his imperial Majesty— That some difficulties had occurred to them with regard to the nature of the stipulation, which had been suggested as desirable by Mr: Daschkoff— The People of the United States were so extensively engaged in commercial Navigation to all parts of the world, that the traffic with the Indians on the North-west Coast could not be prevented, but by special prohibitions of Law— Prohibitions, which it would seem almost, if not altogether impracticable to carry fully into Execution— The Russians were a Nation not so much addicted to Navigation as my Countrymen; and yet he the Count was well aware, how ineffectual the prohibitions to send vessels to particular foreign Countries were, to prevent them from going there— If such was the experience of this Government, the difficulties must obviously be much greater in preventing a trade so distant, with wandering savages, scattered along a Coast over several degrees of latitude; having no Ports, no Custom-houses, not even permanent dwelling places, from which it would be possible to collect evidence of any transgression of the Law— That even were a Convention concluded to prohibit this traffic, the Indians would probably still get their supplies; if not from our vessels, yet from the English; either by water, or by land from the British Settlements North of us. And although nothing could be easier than to draw an Article of a Convention to prohibit the trade, it would indicate a want of frankness and candour in the United States to contract engagements, and then find them not executed— For though it should arise from a state of things not within their controul, it would be manifest that such a State of things ought to have been considered before the contract was formed. I was however instructed to enquire, what would be the boundary line, within which it was the wish of this Government to extend the prohibition? A Question which I had already intimated in the former conference— The Count answered me, that he would render to the Emperor an exact report of the observations I had now made to him— That it was an object concerning which they had no great solicitude— Their first idea had been that this trade with the Indians, especially as to the Article of fire-arms, might be as detrimental to the United States themselves as to the Russian settlement and more so. That in that point of view the United-States might find it expedient to issue the prohibition, provided it were compatible with our Constitutions.— He did not think it possible for these supplies of arms to be furnished to those Indians from the British Settlements by Land. But with regard to a mutual stipulation, he candidly confessed there was no basis— To engage that the Russians should not thus traffic would be nugatory, as no Russian vessels traded there— And there was no privilege, which could be granted for trade with the Russian settlement, but what now existed de facto— The trade of all Nations there was perfectly free— As to the fixing a boundary, it would be most advisable to defer that to some future time; for the sake of avoiding all possible collision, and even every pretext for jealousy or uneasiness— In the present State of the World, the first and strongest wish of his Heart was to bring all the civilized Nations to pacific dispositions, and most carefully to avoid every thing which could strike a single new spark of discord out among them.— At any rate I might be assured of the continuance of the Emperor’s amicable dispositions towards the United States— They were as strong and fixed as they ever had been; and he might even say stronger— Our attachment to the United States, says he, I assure you is obstinate— More obstinate than you are aware of.— I replied that I understood the force of the term which he had used— That if there were particulars of which I was uninformed, I knew full well in a general point of view the attachment to which he alluded, and that most certainly it should not remain unknown to the Government of the United States. That indeed a comparison between the measures not only of France, but of all the neighbours of Russia, in the North of Europe, Denmark, Prussia, Sweden, with regard to the commerce of the United States, with those of Russia, during the present year, would of itself be a strong indication to the Government, and to the People of the United States, of a disposition in Russia, very different from that which they have experienced
elsewhere, and it was impossible they could be insensible to it— I had learnt however from some of my Countrymen, lately arrived here after detention at Copenhagen, that there had been some measures of restriction upon the privateers, and some others favourable to the Americans, lately adopted by the Danish Government— There had obviously been a change also lately in the policy of France— The project of cutting off all commerce between the British Islands and the Continent could no longer be pursued, since licences were openly offered for sale by authority of the French Government at Hamburg— But, said the Count, there is an Embargo— The Government there, do not allow the vessels to sail— I said that I had private advices, that every vessel with a French licence was understood to be exempted from the operation of the Embargo, and might go when and where it pleased. But, said he, there is a new edict of the Emperor Napoleon, forbidding all such vessels from taking any passengers; and in my own opinion there is no real change in the policy of France— The Ministers and People about the Emperor prevail upon him sometimes to sign edicts and ordinances which they think and represent as changes of his policy, but they find themselves mistaken— His intentions remain the same— He thinks the only means by which he can influence England, is by distressing the English commerce, and that is after all his real object— Now as much as ever— I said that I believed this opinion correct; but certainly the means to the end were continually changing; and the experiment upon which he now seemed to rely was to levy upon importations the most excessive duties—which if really levied must ultimately fall upon his own People the consumers— I then mentioned the case of the Havanna sugars arrived in American vessels at Archangel; and which the revisor at that Port, and Baron Campenhausen has taken for refined sugars broken up and powdered— On which they had suspected and accused the importers of having endeavoured to introduce them by fraud, and having brought them from England— I immediately saw by the manner in which the Count talked upon this subject, what I have all along suspected, that there is a purpose behind the curtain in this affair— He first asked me whether I did not think they might possibly be refined sugars powdered, and that there had been an attempt to introduce them as raw, to evade the payment of the heavier duties— I said I believed it impossible— These vessels came from the United States with all the regular documents, including certificates from the Russian Consuls— I knew some of the merchants who had expedited them, and did not believe they would lend themselves to such an attempt to defraud the Russian Government— I knew the nature of the Havanna white Sugar, and the ease with which it might be mistaken for refined loaf-sugar powdered— But the expence of powdering whole Cargoes of loaf-sugar, would be far greater than the saving in the difference of the duties— The first cost of loaf sugar to break down, would be double, what these sugars are offered for and actually sold in the market here— There was no possibility of profit, but the utmost certainty of a heavy loss, in the attempt which was suspected— There was besides the easiest of all possible means to ascertain the fact by boiling down an equal quantity of refined sugar and of that in question— The result would immediately shew the difference between them.— But said he, if there is this similarity between them that they are so liable to be mistaken for each other, I should recommend to the Emperor to prohibit their importation—(this is the true secret) for at least it opens a door to fraud, and may deprive the revenues of the duties on refined sugars— And indeed, before I quitted the Department of Commerce, I had similar informations reported to me of the importation here at St: Petersburg of refined sugars under the name of powdered raw— I said that if the Emperor should consider the interests of His Empire as requiring a prohibition that the white Havanna sugars should henceforth in future be imported into this Country, it would undoubtedly be a misfortune for us; but the Emperor must certainly decide as he thought fit— I could not however myself conceive a motive for excluding a raw sugar, superior in quality more than in price to the others, fit as any others for refinement by the manufactures of the Country, and which could be mistaken for refined sugar, only because untill recently, it had been very little known and imported here— That the quantities in which it now came arose I presumed from the free admission of our vessels, and the great increase of our trade with the Island of Cuba, under the new Government which it had assumed— And I had observed that among the Articles which the new Government of Caraccas had permitted to be imported from the United States, Russian Manufactures were included— I supposed the Government at the Havanna had done the same— I said I was glad of this opportunity of conversing with him upon those Events, which seemed to me to be of transcendent importance, not only to us; but to the General Politics of Europe— (I knew this was touching upon a string to which the Count’s feelings would respond— They did so instantaneously—) He said that it would have been impossible for himself to have expressed more exactly his opinion than I had just done— He asked me, whether we
had before the late Revolutions in the Spanish Colonies, any Commerce with the Havanna, and whether our vessels had been admitted there— Whether I knew what sort of Government they now had there— Whether they had sent any Ministers or Agents to the United States; and whether I thought they would be able and would adhere to the intention of maintaining themselves in a State of Independence— I told him that our vessels had always been admitted at the Havanna— That like many others of the West-India Islands, they depended in some measure upon the Continent of North-America for subsistence— That we had therefore always enjoyed a trade with them arising from their necessities; and it had always been very valuable— But undoubtedly the late revolutions had very much increased it— That I was not accurately informed what the Nature of their Government was; nor whether they had agents or Ministers in the United States— I had nothing upon the subject from the Government, and only saw by the Newspapers that they had sent agents to Washington who had not however been recognized— That as to their maintaining their Independence, that would probably depend upon Events and arrangements in Europe— If the war should terminate in the establishment of a Sovereign of the Buonaparte family or appointment in Spain, undoubtedly the Colonies of that Nation would no longer continue in that relation. The sentiment of the People, both upon the American Continent, and in the Spanish Islands was so unanimous and so strongly pronounced on this point that they could never again be made dependences upon Spain, under that Government, unless by conquest; which Spain would not be very able, nor I believe France very willing to undertake— The Emperor Napoleon, nearly a year since had declared himself ready and willing to acknowledge the Independence of the Spanish Colonies, if the People of the Countries themselves desired it— That they would desire it in preference to dependence upon his Spanish Monarchy was beyond all question; and it seemed to me a thing altogether conformable to the interest of all the European continental powers— The only obstacle of serious import that I could foresee to this result would come from England— She could not help perceiving, that it must give the death blow to the old colonial system of Europe; which was founded upon the contracted and despicable basis of monopoly between the Colony and its European Master— If once the Spanish and Portugueze Colonies on the American Continent, and all the considerable Islands in their neighbourhood acquire Independence, and of course the enjoyment of a free trade with all the world, England will make but a sorry figure with her exclusion of all trade but her own with her petty islands of Barbadoes and Jamaica— There was it seemed to me already some Evidence of the jealousy with which England had witnessed the late manifestations of Independence in the Spanish Colonies— I observed that the Junta at Cadix had issued a proclamation against them; with a declaration that they had ordered a naval force to be stationed so as to blockade them— Now as to a blockade by the naval forces of the Junta at Cadix, it would be only matter of ridicule, if it referred for execution only to their own— But I concluded that in publishing this paper they were assured of the co-operation of British naval forces for their blockade, and strongly suspect that it was under British instigation that they issued the manifesto. If such be the case it most clearly demonstrates in what light the English Government consider these Events— But whatever Britain might think, or wish, this course of Events is too mighty for her controul— Can she recover Spain for Ferdinand 7. and Portugal for the Prince of Brazil?— As to Ferdinand 7. said the Count, I consider the use of his name in the present stage of affairs as absurd, and becoming ridiculous. A Prince in a foreign Country—a prisoner, in possession of another Sovereign; without a prospect of ever being restored— It is impossible that the American Colonies should remain even nominally under his Government— Then said I, without hesitation I do give it as my opinion that all the Spanish Colonies will be either Independent, or at least have an existence totally different from that which they have been under from the discovery of Columbus to these times— If France and the European Continental powers chuse, it will be Independence— As to Brazil its Independence is already declared— The removal of the royal family of Portugal, was in the result; nothing more nor less than a declaration of Independence, for the Portugueze Colonies in America— Accordingly England has just been making a Treaty of Commerce with the Prince Regent; and I doubt not he will find it for his interest to make another Treaty with the United States, and with any other European Power as well as with England. The Count enquired whether we had a Minister there. I told him of Mr: Sumter’s appointment, and that the newspapers mentioned his having arrived at Rio Janeiro— Of which however I had no official advice— By this time Mr: Navarro was announced as being in the antichamber waiting; and I rose to take my
leave— The Count with much earnestness expressed his regret at being interrupted in this conversation, and again assured me with great apparent satisfaction of his most entire and perfect coincidence of opinion with me on this subject— Before leaving him I mentioned Mr: Jones’s desire to be presented at Court, to the Emperor— I told him that Mr: Jones had been a fellow-traveller with Mr: Poinsett, who had given him such a favorable idea of Russia, that he had come as a traveller to visit the Country— The Count enquired what was Mr: Jones’s condition in life; adding however an apology for the question, and intimating that he did not wish me to be very particular in the answer. I told him that Mr: Jones was a young Gentleman, of a respectable family; who had no particular profession— His father was wealthy, and he was now traveling for his own pleasure and improvement— He asked what was the father’s occupation, and I told him he was a merchant— The Count asked me to give him the Gentleman’s name; which I did; and he said he would take the Emperor’s orders concerning it— The Emperor returns this day to the Winter Palace, from his Summer Residence at Kammenoi Ostroff— As I left the Count I met Mr: Navarro going in— I came home, and read my letters from America, and the Anthology Criticism of my Lectures— It is tolerably well-written; but full of inconsistency, and excessive both in praise and blame—especially the praise— Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray dined with us— In the Evening I read to the Ladies l’Important—a Comedy of Brueys and Palaprat. Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Jones came and spent an hour with us, after the Play.

10. I was employed almost the whole of this day in writing down the account of my interview with Count Romanzoff— My custom of thus recording as nearly as my recollection will serve every thing that is said in these Conferences, I believe to be a very good one; but in a very active negotiation it would be impracticable— It would be prodigiously facilitated, if I were master of short-hand writing— I lament that I did not learn this effectually in my youth. It is now too late— I received some letters again this day from America, and from Christiansand— Also from Amsterdam and Hamburg with information that General Armstrong has left Paris for Bordeaux, to embark for America— In the Evening I read L’evesque.

11. Mr: Plummer and Mr: Morse called this morning on me— Mr: Plummer told me that Mr: Donovan, and Mr: Norman, having embarked and sailed from Cronstadt, had been compelled by contrary winds to return; and had come back to St: Petersburg, with the intention of going by land to Gottenburg, and embarking there for England. I paid a visit to Captain Bainbridge, Mr: Lynch and Mr: Lewis, but found neither of them at his lodgings— I found however Mr: Donovan; who promised to take letters for me for England— He expects to go in two or three days— Mr: Donovan now explained to me the nature of his complaint against Messrs: Meyer and Brüxner, for overcharging him in his account— He read me the copy of letter which he had written this morning to Mr: Harris, enclosing one of his last letter to Meyer and Bruxner— And while I was with him he received Mr: Harris’s Answer, returning him with a refusal to receive it the copy of the letter to Meyer & Bruxner, and the letter to himself enclosing it.— He read me Mr Harris’s Answer, which was in cool and considerate terms— Mr: Donovan’s observations upon it were equally so. I asked him if he had obtained the extract from the Custom-house of the duties actually paid on his imported Cargo— He had not— But he had obtained the order for it from the Minister— And then he had received a letter from a certain Notary public, broker, and interpreter, imploring his Compassion for the expeditor, and custom-house collector and receiver, and intreating him not to pursue any further his enquiry on this subject, as it would involve them and their families in irretrievable ruin. This was proof as decisive for his purpose, as the extracts from the duties themselves— These were the people, who by underweighing and underguaging, entered goods at the custom-house, for about half what they ought to be entered— The consignment merchants made their foreign correspondents pay the whole duties; but by suitable inducements prevailed upon these expeditors, and custom-house weighers and gaugers to reduce the entries about one half— This double plunder from the foreign Correspondents and the Government here was thus shared between the Consignees, and these Custom-house subalterns— The Clerks and yet inferior waiters there seeing all this management and able to ruin those who practice it by informing against them steal to the amount of about ten per Cent upon all the deposited goods, and make the connivence of their superiors to these thefts, the price of their silence at the malversations of those Superiors— As his evidence was adequate to his object, he had been unwilling to ruin the poor subalterns the mere instruments of these frauds, and he had pursued his inquiries no further— He also appeared fully convinced that he knew the origin and sole cause of the transactions respecting the Havanna sugars seized at Archangel. The Commission there knew them to be Havanna sugars, as well as the Importers— Nothing was easier than to distinguish them from
refined sugars— But last year the consignment merchants at Archangel, had charged all their American Correspondents large sums, for obtaining what they called facilities; that is for conciliating the favour of the Commission for neutral Navigation— But they had really given to the Commissioners not more than one quarter part of it, and kept the other three fourths for themselves. The Commissioners had been informed of this, and as long ago as last Winter had acquainted the Merchants, that they should in due time be punished for defrauding them of their honest perquisites; and hence arose this supposed mistake of raw for refined sugars— The private interest of the Cramer’s and the Severin’s did the rest— As Petersburg merchants they are jealous of the Archangel trade— As sugar-refiners, they are jealous of other refineries lately erected on the Wolga by merchants of Archangel— If the sugars in question had been seized and confiscated, they might have been purchased at low prices, for the refinery of the Severin’s and Cramer’s, and hence the opinion so readily given by Peter Severin, his refiner and Benedict Cramer, that the samples were refined sugar— Such are Mr: Donovan’s opinions, probably somewhat tinctured by his resentments— After leaving him, as I was walking on the Mall in front of the admiralty, I met the Emperor, who stop’d and spoke to me— He said the autumn had been finer than the Summer— But as to Summer said he—we have had none—you must have a terrible opinion of our climate— I said that as long as one enjoyed good-health, all climates might be rendered agreeable— You have a countryman arrived, I hear, said his Majesty— yes Sire.— Mr: Jones (said he)—an acquaintance, I am told of Mr: Poinsett’s— Yes Sire. Mr: Poinsett carried home with him such agreeable ideas of his visit to Russia, that he inspired Mr: Jones with the desire of visiting the same Country— And where did Mr: Jones see Mr: Poinsett— They returned in company together from Europe to America— what? Has Mr: Jones been in Europe before?— Yes, Sire—he has travelled in France, Italy and England.— What? and returned to Europe again?—perhaps, upon his private business?— Sire! he is a young man of Fortune; who travels for his pleasure, and to acquire instruction— After having been once in Europe, and returned home, the taste for traveling was not satiated, and he has come a second time— He must then have a strong taste for it indeed; for such a voyage as that is not like crossing the Neva— My Countrymen Sire, are so familiarized with the Ocean, that they think not much more of crossing it, than of going over a river— I enquired how his Majesty had enjoyed his health? perfectly well said he— And added with a significant smile—Ce ne sera pas le physique qui me tuera—ce sera le moral—upon which we parted— I collected from his last words, that there were subjects under his consideration, which gave him some concern— Walking afterwards upon the Quay I met Dr: Creichton, who walk’d with me— He has been for some weeks at Pavlofsky attending the Grand Duchess Catherine, who he told me was threatened with a bad Breast— Neither her own child nor any other being able to draw the excess of milk which she has after her confinement— She is now in the City; but will see no company, and intends to leave the City on her return to the Prince her husband’s Government the 16th: of next month.— On returning home I found a Note from Count Romanzoff, informing me that Mr: Jones would have the honour to be presented to their Imperial Majesties at the first diplomatic circle.— In the Evening I went with the Ladies to the German Play, and saw the Opera of Achilles— Music of Paer, and very excellent.

12. About ten o’clock this morning, as I was preparing a letter to send by Mr: Donovan, came the Messenger from the Grand Maitre des Cérémonies, to inform me that two ships would be launched at the Admiralty— The hour fixed for this, was half past twelve at Noon; but it would probably be about one— And the members of the Corps diplomatique were invited to attend if they pleased— Feeling uncertain where to go, and how to proceed, in order to be in the rule of etiquette, I called upon Mr: Navarro, who had been at similar ceremonies before— He told me that being not very well he did not intend to go— But that in proceeding to the Admiralty, I should find there some of the Officers of the Department of the Ceremonies who would shew me, where the Corps Diplomatique were stationed— Navarro then told me what his errand was the other day when I met him at Count Romanzoff’s— It was to announce the appointment of a Minister from the Prince Regent of Brazil to this Court—a Monsieur de Bedzara; and he shewed me the answer which he had just received from Count Romanzoff, to this Communication. It express’d the Emperor’s great satisfaction, at receiving this information, and his determination to appoint a Minister to the Prince regent in return— This led us into some conversation, and I expressed to Mr: Navarro very sincerely my regret, that this event would occasion his departure— I was first acquainted with him as the Secretary of the Vicount d’Anadia, at Berlin— I have seen much more of him here; and found in him a worthy and honourable man. Having been here now six or seven years he is well acquainted with the Country; and I have often obtained from him just information of current events— I was obliged to leave him and dress for the launching— Went with Mr: W. S. Smith; just at one O’Clock— We were within one minute of being too late— The Emperor,
and his Court were already there— We had barely got inside of the Admiralty yard, when the Posts under the first ship, the three Saints, were knocked away, and she descended majestically upon the bosom of the flood. I found neither Messenger from the department of the Ceremonies; nor Corps Diplomatique— But I came to the Platform where the Emperor & Empress were standing, and saw the Second ship St: Eustaphie, rush down upon the river, as advantageously as it could be seen any where. They were both seventy-four gun ships, and very finely built. The whole ceremony was over within a quarter of an hour after I arrived— The concourse of People was very great— As I was coming out I met the Grand Master of Ceremonies Narishkin, who apologized for the lateness of his notice, and said he knew nothing of it himself untill last Night at Midnight.— I came home, undress’d, and walked on the Quay below the Bridge to see the two ships as they were anchor’d in the river— The Bridge had been taken away to let them pass— Mr: J. S. Smith, Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray dined with us— Mr: Jones was here part of the Evening.

13. Morning visits from Mr: Montréal and Mr: Harris— I made up my packets for the Secretary of State; and for Mr: Pinkney, to go by Mr: Donovan— Mr: Smith took them to him; and he was on the point of departure— I exchanged my usual walk upon the Quay of the Neva, for that upon the Fontanka, and through the Newsky Perspective. Mr: Everett & Mr: Gray dined with us— They all went in the Evening with the Ladies to the French theatre— General Watzdorff the Saxon Minister paid me a visit— I finished reading the first volume of Levesque’s History of Russia. It comes down about to the year 1200 of the Christian Era. The historian frequently introduced reflections; but the narrative of those early ages of this, as of all other histories, is so confused, and the personages so uninteresting that to read through a volume of it, is like wading over a sand-mountain— I can scarcely keep myself awake in going through it—and when gone through, it leaves scarcely a trace of memory behind.

14. The first Sunday for many weeks, that I have been without interruption through the day— I employed it, in writing to my Mother; and in reading Massillon’s Panegyric of St: John-Baptist, and Robinson’s life of Moses— The Gentlemen of the family all dined abroad. I was out only for an hour’s walk before dinner.— The Panegyrics of Massillon are his most indifferent works: I was disappointed in this one of John-Baptist, of which I had formed high expectations from the character of the subject— The division is in the author’s manner— John Baptist condemns the World by his Holiness; and the World condemns John Baptist, for his Holiness— The mutual opposition and condemnation of each other between Sanctity and Worldly-mindedness constitutes the partition of the whole discourse— It is not one of those studded with odd figures, and strangely applied scriptural allusions— The biography of the Saint was not so necessary for me, as that of the others in the volume; because all that is known of him is contained in the New-Testament— The life of Moses in Robinson is longer than those of the preceding Characters; but I find not much useful knowledge in it.

15. Mr: Jewett called upon me this morning with a request that I would apply to Count Romanzoff for a special Passport to enable him to embark at Cronstadt and go to Gothenburg— He has chartered a vessel under Russian Colours, and having neglected to apply for his Passport to the Police-Office in time, cannot now procure one, untill it may be too late for him to sail this Season. I wrote to Count Romanzoff accordingly— Went and examined some table linen, and several carriages advertised for sale— Walked home by the way of the foundery— Mr: Jones paid me a morning visit; and he, with Mr: Harris—Mr: J. S. Smith, and the other Gentlemen pass’d the Evening with us. I began reading the second volume of L’Evesque’s Russian History.

16. Mr: Montréal called upon me this morning, with some further information, concerning the State of Affairs in this Country— Mr: J. S. Smith came to mention his intention to go to Paris, in the course of a few weeks from this time. He seems however not to be absolutely decided— In my walk before dinner, I met General Pardo, who says he is fort ennuyé since his return to the diplomatic Convent; and who complains that the atmosphere is loaded with poppies— Mr: Gray did not dine with us— I received a Note from Count Romanzoff, enclosing a Passport for Mr: Jewett— I called at that Gentleman’s lodgings with it, but he was gone to Cronstadt— Captain Bainbridge had not yet returned. I took this Evening a hot water and a steam bath— It was almost too powerful, though nothing in comparison with those which the Russians are accustomed to take— On returning home, I immediately retired to bed.

17. Mr: Harris was with me this morning, and shewed me two letters from Archangel— They have not yet sent on the documents respecting the sugars. Captain Symonds came again and complained that he could not get his papers from Mr: Küsel; who is Mr: Harris’s agent there— I sent him to Mr: Harris for redress, as Küsel was under his authority and not mine— Mr: Everett came and asked my advice whether to spend the ensuing Winter here, or go to Paris, of which he has the intention— I advised him if he felt Resolution to employ his time in the Study of the Law of Nations to stay here; but if he preferred amusement or the indulgence of Curiosity, to go either to Paris or to London— But after leading his attention to the principal use which he might derive for his own improvement, from either of these Courses, I thought it best to leave the determination to himself.— The Gentlemen all dined out of town, with the party of the Hunt; excepting Mr: W. Smith— In the Evening I went with the Ladies to the Stone Theatre, and saw La Menteur, a Comedy by Pierre Corneille, and le Naufrage ou les Héritiers— The farce was bad—the Comedy amusing, and better written than I had thought; but improbable, romantic, and immoral— The liar is ingenious, brave, amiable, and finally happy— He lies to his father to his mistress, to his friend to his valet and to himself, and finally by a ridiculous change of his affections without the shadow of a motive obtains a Lady in Marriage, and suffers no punishment for his baseness— But there is some good versification, and fine sentiment— The father is the only good character in the play.— Catherine was taken ill, and obliged to come home, before the end of the Comedy— I have taken a Cold, notwithstanding the precautions which I took after the bath.

18. Though I had a day of leisure, and a morning free from interruptions, I wrote very little; and scarcely can tell how the day pass’d. This happens to me but too often, when I am yet not sensible of being idle— I walked through the Summer-Gardens, and found the alleys strewed with the leaves fallen from the trees— Messrs: J. S. Smith, Everett and Gray dined with us In the Evening, I read for about half an hour in Levesque; untill I found myself sleeping over him— The rest of the Evening we all played cards.

19. I was engaged all this morning, in writing to Mr: Gray of Boston— Mr: Stieglitz called upon me for the Passport of Mr: Jewett, which he said was necessary to procure the ship’s papers, and which I delivered to him— I went in the Evening with the Ladies, to the German Theatre where we saw an Opera called die Teuffels mühle am Wienerberg, a hobgoblin story from a popular tale.— We took Charles with us, and he was much diverted with the entertainment— The Music by Wenzel Müller is good; but far inferior to that of Achilles— Mr: Gray came to our box, in the Evening, and came home with us.

20. This was one of those tumultuary days which so often unexpectedly occur, and disconcert all my regular occupations— Before breakfast, Mr: Jewett called upon me, having travell’d most of the Night to come up from Cronstadt. I gave him his despatches for the Department of State, and for Mr: Saabye at Copenhagen— He was so much engaged in preparing for his departure that he could not dine with us— While he was here I received a note from Count Romanzoff, with a Packet of despatches, and letters from America, brought by Prince Alexis Kurakin from Paris— Mr: Jewett was with me nearly two hours, and I did not breakfast untill Noon— Immediately afterwards Mr: Montréal called upon me with a Packet for Mr: Gray, to be sent by Captain Leach. Captain Bainbridge sent me an apology for not dining with us—expecting to be obliged to leave the City— Messrs: Harris, Lewis, Lynch, Tilden, Plummer, Morse, Martin, Jones and all the Gentlemen of the Legation dined with us— Some of them remained in the Evening, and played Cards with the Ladies— I played a couple of games of Chess with Mr. Jones— We had Evening visits first from Mr: Prevost, one of the Secretaries of the French Embassy, and afterwards from the Ambassador himself— I also received an invitation for all the family, to the Children’s masked Ball at his house, next Thursday Evening.

21. The weather was so bad the whole of this day that it confined me altogether to the house; and not being interrupted I wrote part of a long letter to the Secretary of State. Mr: W. S. Smith dined abroad— In the Evening we had a visit from General Watzdorff the Saxon Minister. I read Massillon’s Panegyric of St: Mary Magdalen—and Robinson’s Character of Pharoah. The bishop represents Mary Magdalen, as a person belonging to the higher Class of life—and spoken of as a sinner, only because she led a gay life, and was fond of the dissipations of the world— The Panegyric is not remarkably good— It contains like allmost all Massillon’s discourses a severe censure of theatrical amusements.

22. Received this morning from Count Romanzoff a note, with a packet of Boston Newspapers, and a letter from my brother of 27. March last— I finished my letter to the Secretary of State; and paid visits to the French Ambassador; to Baron Blome, and to General Pardo, the last of whom only I found at home—the Chevalier Brancia, and an Italian miniature painter were with him, when I went in— Count Soltikoff, Mr: Harris and Mr: J. S. Smith came in while I was there— The general shewed me several of his splendid editions of the Greek Classics—among the rest one of Isocrates lately published at Paris; printed by Didot, for the brothers Zosime, who are publishing these books at their own expence, and have them distributed, at the schools, in Greece— He has also the Homer of Hayne, and his Virgil of the last Edition—and the new Homer of Wolf— After my visits I took a long walk— In the Evening I read about two hours in Levesque; but I find myself so heavy and sleepy in reading by Candle-light that I fear I must abandon it altogether— I find my health again affected since the approach of Winter— We played Cards; for I yet can devise no mode of profitable occupation for these long Evenings.

23. We had a snow-storm all this morning; but which turned towards Evening to rain— Mr: Nancarrow called upon me this forenoon and informed me that he should go to-morrow to Cronstadt, to embark with Captain Bainbridge in the Lion— She will sail if the wind permits, the next day— I employed the day in writing to my brother; and in making an extract of the Invoices and account of a Cargo shipped from St: Petersburg; for Boston—which I took to ascertain the nature and amount of charges, and the mode of doing business— In my walk before dinner I met Baron Blome, and Count Lüxbourg, who walked with me— He is a young man of very good understanding, but of a satirical disposition, and who indulges himself in the habit of speaking freely of persons— He told me anecdotes of Mr: d.’Alopeus, who has just returned from Vienna; and of Count St: Julien who is to be the Austrian Minister here, tending to cast a ridicule upon them.— In the Evening Mr: Harris, Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Jones came and pass’d two or three hours with us after the play.

24. Made up the packets to be sent to America by Captain Bainbridge, and wrote also a letter to Mr: Hellen to go by him— Mr: Smith took them all to Mr: Nancarrow, who goes to Cronstadt to-morrow morning— Mr: Smith dined abroad.— In the Evening I went with Mrs: Adams and paid visits to the Grand Chambellan Narishkin, Countess Litta—Countess Prozarofsky, Countess Protassof the Grand-Maitre des Ceremonies Narishkin—M. de Gourieff—the Grand Marechal Count Tolstoi, and Princess Wiezemsky’s— I had called in the morning on Monsieur de Maisonneuve, who now lives at Count Litta’s to make enquiries respecting Mr: Jones’s presentation at Court; and to know whether it is to be on the 26th. M. de Maisonneuve was not at home either, in the morning nor in the Evening visit— But Countess Litta received us— We were also received at Count Tolstoy’s; where we found M. de Maisonneuve and Baron Blome, and M. d’Italinsky.— Mr: Jones is to be presented on the 26th:— There is to be a Court held in the morning; and an Opera at the Hermitage in the Evening; after which a feu d’artifice on the river, and on the quay beyond the river, opposite the Palace— The Ministers of the Corps Diplomatique are to have tickets for the Play at the Hermitage, after which they are to go to a Hall in the Palace, fronting the river to see the fire-works— The Secretaries and some other Strangers, are to have tickets for the Hall to see the fire-works, but not for the Hermitage— A Ticket for the Hermitage is to be sent for Mrs: Adams, and as she is the only Minister’s Lady here, and that she may not be alone; by the express order of the Emperor a ticket is also to be sent to her Sister Catherine, although she has never been presented at Court. At Princess Wiezemsky’s we found Colonel Vlodek, who returned about three weeks since from the Army in Turkey; with his arm in a sling— He was badly wounded at the assault upon Rushtshouk, which failed. Princess Wiezemsky herself has been many months an invalid with the gout; and is yet quite unwell— The Duke de Serra-Capriola was there when we went in, but immediately went away— It was about 11. in the Evening when we got home.

25. Captain Symonds called on me again this morning, and asked me for advice what to do; and to look over his protests
which he told me Mr: Delapré would bring to me— Mr: Delapré brought the papers which I accordingly read— Symonds owes him money for lodgings when he was here before and now; and also for money lent him; and does not know where to look for payment— Symonds is a foolish man who has so little discretion in his conduct that almost every body with whom he has any thing to do thinks him crazy— This does not appear however from his conversation. I advised him to return to Archangel to his ship; and told Mr: Delapré that I would speak to Mr: Harris, to see if the payment of his demand could be secured from any debts due to Symonds at Archangel. Captain Leach came to tell me that he should go down to Cronstadt to-morrow morning, and sail for Boston as soon afterwards as possible— He took some letters with him, and promised to call to-morrow and take any others— I wrote a letter to my mother. Mr: Montréal and Mr: Jones were both here—the former had some new and interesting intelligence. Mr: J. S. Smith also called, and shewed me a letter from Amsterdam, with a new decree of the French Emperor concerning American merchandize in Holland; which occasions much consternation there— In the Evening we went to the children’s masked Ball at the French Ambassador’s— Charles went dress’d as a Bacchus— We went about nine, and were the first there— The Empress mother had a party, and a small play performed, for which the actor was employed, who was to manage the Ambassador’s ombres chinoises, so that he could not come untill eleven O’Clock— Great part of the Company also did not come untill the same time— There were about thirty children and their parents, and perhaps 150 other persons— The children were all in mask dresses; and a few of them at first were masked— They walked the Polonaise— Danced Country dances, and the Russian Golubetz or dove dance; and some others. They supp’d between ten and eleven— Then had the Ombres Chinoises, and about midnight were sent home— I came home myself with Charles and Martha; leaving the ladies and W. S. Smith there— They came home about two; before the Supper—the party finished about 3. in the morning— Count Romanzoff was there, and told me that the Emperor had received a despatch from Count Pahlen, with which he was much pleased— That the Count was highly gratified with his reception, and pleased with the Country— I asked the Count whether he had received my last Note; he said he had, and should answer it.

26. The Empress mother’s birth-day.— I had yesterday received notice that there would be this day at 12 O’Clock a Court at the Winter Palace, and at the same time three tickets for the Play at the Hermitage in the Evening—one for myself, one for Mrs: Adams, and one for Catherine Johnson— At Noon I went with the two Mr: Smith’s and Mr: Jones to the Palace— While we were waiting in the Salle des Ambassadeurs, untill the Mass should be finished, I was enquiring of M. de Maisonneuve respecting the presentation of Mr: Jones to the Grand Dukes, and Grand Duchess Ann, after the Circle, when I found that the Grand Duchess Catherine would also receive presentations. I therefore requested to be presented to her myself; and the same favour for all the gentlemen of the legation excepting Mr: J. S. Smith, who declined— The Circle was held between one and two O’Clock, and all the Imperial family excepting the Grand Duchess-Catherine were present— Mr: Jones was presented; as was a Count Fagnani a Chamberlain of the Emperor Napoleon as king of Italy— After the Circle we waited about three quarters of an hour untill the Gentlemen, together with General Watzdorf the Saxon Minister, and Count Lüxbourg as Bavarian Charge des Affairs had been presented to the young Grand Dukes and the Grand Duchess Ann; after which they returned, and we were all presented to the Grand-Duchess Catherine, and her husband Prince George of Holstein Oldenburg, at their apartments— General Watzdorf and myself were presented separately, and the rest of the Gentlemen all together— The Grand-Duchess spoke of Mr: Smith and Mr: Poinsett; and asked some questions about America; whether I had lately heard from there, and how long it took for vessels to come— The Duke also who stood by her side made some observation which I scarcely remember— She is about the middle-size, with a beautiful countenance; expressive eyes, and a fascinating smile— It was nearly four O’Clock, when we returned to from the Palace. And at half past-six immediately after dinner we went there again— About seven we went in to the Theatre at the Hermitage— The Emperor and imperial family came about 8. they sat in a row of Chairs immediately behind the Orchestra. the French Ambassador sat in the same line the last person at the right hand of the Emperor,
and next to the Grand Duke Michael— The Great Crown Officers and Ladies, with Count Stedingk, and Count St: Julien sat in chairs behind them and on the lowest range of benches forming the amphitheatre for the Spectators. For there are no boxes—the Ministers of the Corps Diplomatique sat on the right hand second row, and all the others were filled with the nobility of the Country—the men on the left side, and the women on the right. The french Opera of Cendrillon was performed for the first time— The music partly of Nicolo the original composer; and partly of Stey belt, set here—the play is splendid—the music agreable, and the ballets as usual. Duport danced very well— Two of the songs were encored by a signal from the Grand Chambellan, by the Emperor’s order— About 11. at Night the Opera was over, and we travelled over the Palace to view from the Emperor’s Apartments the fireworks— Those upon the Water did not well succeed; owing probably to the high wind that blew— There was a blue palace of lamps beyond the river—very well executed; and the bouquet or wheat-sheaf of rockets with which it concluded was handsome— About half-past twelve at Night it was all finished and we returned home— M. de Maisonneuve again repeated to me, that the Emperor himself had written the name of Miss Johnson as one of the persons to whom tickets for the Hermitage should be sent, and that it was a very extraordinary mark of distinction. M. de Maisonneuve was very attentive in accompanying the Ladies, after the Play, untill we left the Palace to come home.

27. Mr: Harris called upon me this morning, and had some conversation with me respecting the dispute which he has with Mr: Donovan— He has received the protest and letter which Mr: Donovan left behind to be delivered to him; with which he is highly offended. I told him what had pass’d between Mr: Donovan and me upon this subject before his departure— As Donovan threatens both a publication in the American Newspapers, and to make a complaint against Mr: Harris to the Department of State, this Gentleman is naturally very much concerned, and not without some agitation at this state of things— I told him every thing of which Donovan had complained against him, excepting perhaps the most important incident, which requiring some delicacy in the Communication, I reserved for another occasion— He assured me that so far as respected himself he should have in his power the means of a complete justification— That Mr: Donovan’s charges against him were unjust, and unwarrantable, which he could prove, but as to the facts alledged by Donovan, he did not explicitly deny any of them— He declared his determination to prosecute him for a libel; and seemed to think he was punishable for having protested against him in his official capacity— They are indeed somewhat rigorous in their restrictions upon Notarial protests; but I told Mr: Harris that in our Country People were allowed to protest against almost every thing— With regard to the substance of Donovan’s complaints against the brothers Cramer, I told Mr: Harris, that in objects of controversy between individuals I never settled my opinion, upon hearing only one party; but that if Donovan’s story was true, I should consider him as an excessively ill-used man; and should be disposed to make great allowances for his very natural resentment— He said that the brothers Cramer had treated him very ill, himself; so that he had broken off all social intercourse with them; especially with the elder brother Benedict— But that since they had received the protest and letter of Mr: Donovan, and found them selves in difficulty, Mr: B. Cramer had written to him, and called upon him, to ask his assistance to defend them against Mr: Donovan’s charges— That as to the affair of Mr: Donovan’s wines, he believed they would not find it easy to justify them entirely—They had under the appearance of a sale to Mr: Lopez, actually purchased the wines themselves—but he Harris, solemnly declares that he knew nothing about it, and rather more faintly, that he had not derived any profit from it— He is however perfectly confident of his own full justification— I had also some conversation with him respecting Captain Symonds, and the necessity of making some provision from the monies due to him, for the payment of his debts and support of his necessary expences— He promised to speak upon the subject to Mr: Martin, and I hope something will be done to secure the payment of Delapré’s bills— Mr: Jones and the Gentlemen of the family pass’d the Evening with us, partly at Cards— I wrote half a letter to my brother in the Evening.

28. Mr: Jones came this morning, and I gave him the lists of the persons to whom visits by Cards are to be made. And a number of my own Cards to be sent with his— Mr: Harris and Mr: J. S. Smith dined and pass’d the Evening with us— Mr: Gray dined abroad. Baron Blome paid us a visit in the Evening— I read Massillon’s Panegyric upon St: Bernard— It is one of the best in the Volume— The Bishop’s bitterness against the Protestants, against the Great, and against Theatres appears in this as in almost all his other works— His Saint preached one of the unsuccessful Crusades to Palestine, and he makes an attempt equally unsuccessful to celebrate this folly as a virtue— St: Bernard never did I believe much good to the world— But his example like that of the other founders of the monastic orders, proves how great things men accomplish by industry, self-chastisement and perseverance— These may truly be called the royal virtues. They are made in all ages and in every state of Society to have dominion over mankind— But their application is quite as important as the qualities themselves— I was taken up in the Evening so that I could read nothing in Robinson.— Mrs: Adams this Evening was quite unwell.

29. Mr: Montréal paid me a morning visit— I finished a letter for my brother to send by Captain Leach if there is yet time, and began one for the Secretary of State— Took a short walk, in which I met General Watzdorf— He told me of the late king of Sweden’s having embarked at Riga, on board the English armed brig Tartar— I dined at Baron Blome’s in the City; with a company of about twenty persons.— Count and Baron Bussche—Count Schenk—General Watzdorf—Count Lüxbourg, Baron’s Mülinen and Arnim—General Hitroff, Colonel Vlodek, Mr: Harris, Mr: J. S. Smith, Mr: Labensky &c.— I came home immediately after dinner, and we had Cards in the Evening at home— Charles was unwell.

30. Mr: Harris called upon me with a letter from the Americans at Archangel, jointly addressed to himself and to me; complaining of the difficulties which they have found there in transacting their business, and accompanied with a number of Certificates respecting the Havanna sugars— Mr: Jones and Mr: Montréal likewise called upon me— In my morning walk, I met and walked with Count Lüxbourg, who spoke to me of a Mlle: de Mouravieff a maid of honour, to the Grand Duchess Catherine. Mr: J. S. Smith dined with us— I attempted to read in the Evening, but was obliged to give it up; finding myself so much overpowered with sleepiness. We therefore closed the Evening with Cards.

31. Visit this morning from Count Bussche the Westphalian Minister, with his three daughters— Also from Mr: Harris— I took my customary morning’s walk, and met General Pardo— I paid a visit likewise to Mr: Navarro, and returned him the copy that he had lent me of the Treaty of Bartenstein; between Russia and Prussia, which preceded about six weeks the Treaty of Tilsit. Mr: W. S. Smith dined abroad— The other Gentlemen and the Ladies pass’d the Evening at Cards, but as I found myself this Evening able to read, I finished the second volume of Levesque’s History of Russia— From the accession of Ivan III. Vassilievitch in 1462. the History becomes in some degree interesting— This was the Prince who shook off the Tartar domination which had been established three Centuries.— He also became the sovereign over the Republic of Novgorod.

Day— I rise usually between 7. and 8. O’Clock; that is to say at present about full daylight— Read five Chapters in Ostervald’s french Bible, with his reflections; and occasionally compare it with the English Bible; there is sometimes a remarkable difference between the Translations— Write the journal of the preceding day; but sometimes I neglect it, and sometimes it is too long to be finished before breakfast; in either case I have the arrears to bring up afterwards— From half past ten to eleven is the hour of breakfast. From which time untill near four P.M— I am employed in writing letters, or in receiving or paying visits. From three to five is destined to my walk, on the Quay of the Neva, or in other parts of the City; at 5. we dine; and it is now by candle-light. After dinner, I pay or receive visits, attend the Theatre, play Cards, or spend the Evening in my Cabinet, reading or writing. Between 11. and midnight I retire to bed— From dinner time I begin to experience some tedious hours, owing to the weakness of my eyes, and the sleepy heaviness which prevents me from taking any satisfaction in reading.
